text: IRM 6.300.2, Special Employment Programs, dated August 1, 2002, has been superseded. Current and applicable guidance previously found in IRM 6.300.2 and other official Servicewide policy have been moved to this and other IRMs, which have been renumbered to follow the numbering format in Title 5 of the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR).
NATURE OF MATERIAL

IRM 6.304.1 provides Servicewide policy, standards, requirements, and guidance relating to the administration of employing experts and consultants and processing guidance for the appointment of experts for the Art Advisory Panel of the Commissioner. This IRM must be read and interpreted in accordance with pertinent law, Governmentwide regulations, Treasury Human Resources Directives, and applicable case law. All previous official Servicewide policy, guidance, requirements, and authorities formerly contained in memoranda, guides, and other documents are incorporated into this IRM, if current and applicable.

For employees in bargaining units covered by negotiated agreements, appropriate negotiated agreement provisions relating to subjects in this Chapter should also be reviewed. For bargaining unit employees, should any of these instructions conflict with a provision of a negotiated agreement, the agreement will prevail.

Consultant Appointments

) The Department of the Treasury (Treasury) has the authority to approve the appointment of experts and consultants without the prior approval of the of Personnel Management (OPM). This authority has not been delegated to bureaus. IRS requests for authority to appoint experts and consultants are approved by the Treasury only after a determination that all pertinent ments are met. (
) References: (cid:

) Before an expert or consultant position is established, a determination must made that: of a. The position is necessary; b. The work cannot effectively and more appropriately be performed by a current employee; c. The position requires the services of an expert or consultant; d. Consultants will be assigned to carry out advisory work, not to carry out operating functions; e. The position has properly been designated as temporary or intermittent; and that work which is really temporary in nature is not classified as mittent to permit employment beyond one year, or to permit payment for travel expenses which could not be made to temporary appointees; and f. The proposed expert or consultant authority is not a substitute for more appropriate authorities (for example, to permit the employment of als not available competitively or at salaries not otherwise permitted). (

) A full position description is not required, but a written statement should be ficient to show that the type of work to be performed is consistent with the services of an expert or consultant and the nature of qualifications required. (

) On an annual basis, bureaus within Treasury will report the number of days worked and total amount paid to each expert or consultant employed for pensation. (For experts and consultants paid on a per diem basis, any part a day worked counts as one day). (

) Experts and Consultants cannot be appointed to: a. Senior Executive Service positions; or b. Managerial or supervisory positions (although an expert may act as leader or director of the specific project for which he/she is hired). (

The proposed expert or consultant authority is not a substitute for more appropriate authorities (for example, to permit the employment of als not available competitively or at salaries not otherwise permitted).

An appointment under 5 USC § 3109 may only be made to an expert or con- sultant position as defined in 5 CFR § 304.102. Although these positions are not subject to the Classification Act of 1949, it is Treasury’s policy that ments are only made to positions equivalent to GS-13 or above.
Appointments may be intermittent (without a regularly scheduled tour of duty) or temporary (with a full-time, part-time, seasonal, or intermittent work
Expert and Consultant schedule). If intermittent, the appointment may be without time limit or for a specified time period; if temporary, the appointment cannot exceed one year. (

) An expert or consultant who works on a part-time or intermittent schedule be reappointed to perform substantially the same duties with no limit on the number of reappointments, as long as the individual has worked less than
hours (or
months) within his or her current service year. The service year is the calendar year that begins on the date of the individual’s initial ap- pointment in the agency. See
CFR §

) An expert or consultant who works full-time may be reappointed to perform substantially the same duties only once, for a maximum of two years of em- ployment (one year initial appointment and one additional year). (
) Unless specifically authorized by an appropriation or other statute, pay may be set at the equivalent of the base pay rate for any grade and step between GS-
and GS-

This is based on the level and difficulty of work performed; the qualifications of the individuals; pay rates for comparable and the availability of qualified candidates. Pay may be determined on an hourly or daily basis, but (
) aggregate pay for any one day cannot exceed daily rate of base pay for a GS-
, and (
) aggregate pay for any period cannot exceed the biweekly rate of base pay for a GS-
) An expert or consultant may be employed without compensation provided the individual submits a written waiver in advance. (

) An employee who undertakes service with two departments or agencies shall inform each department or agency about his/her arrangements with the other. Each department or agency should estimate the amount of employee service for the period of employment. The sum of the two estimates should be in ac- cordance with
CFR §

) Before an expert or consultant is recommended for appointment, a tion must be made that: a. The appointee clearly has the high level of expertise required to serve either as expert or consultant; b. Pay rates proposed are appropriate and justifiable in terms of the duties be performed and the qualifications of the appointee; c. A tax check has been completed in accordance with IRM

below; d. Other employment and financial interests of the expert or consultant do not constitute a conflict of interest in relationship to the duties to be performed; and e. No preference was given to the proposed appointee based on any prior Federal service. (
) Employees who separate from the Service must refrain from making unfair of their prior positions and affiliations. (

Appointments

) The industrial psychologist can be of considerable help in selecting and utilizing behavior science consultants. They can recommend competent, - respected consultants, whose expertise is particularly relevant to given organizational needs. They are also available to evaluate would-be consult- ants’ proposals in terms of relevance, feasibility, and technical quality. At the same time, they can explore the possibility of using resources within the IRS meet organizational needs. (

) Suggested criteria for selection of a Behavioral Science Consultant, a Psy- chologist, or a Consultant Psychologist follows. These are only suggestions and should not be employed rigidly or without considering individual circum- stances or consultant attributes. In general, a reputable consultant will: a. Be certified in the state in which he/she is practicing; b. Be affiliated with a reputable consulting firm, university, or research c. Be highly regarded by former and/or present clients who are familiar his/her work; and d. Have a graduate level education (usually a MS or P
) in his/her field expertise or competence. (
) The most important method of evaluation is in IRM

)(c) above. consultant who has proven himself/herself at other organizations can usually be expected to perform well for the IRS. However, in speaking with former clients of the consultant, care should be taken to determine what services were performed, when they were performed, and the actual ment of the consultant in the company. Very often “in-company” personnel researchers who have observed the consultant at work will provide the most accurate evaluation. (

Appointments

) The procedures for appointing experts for the Art Advisory Panel of the missioner are outlined in this section to ensure timely submission of requests to Treasury; and to ensure adherence to regulations, policies, and procedures governing the appointment of Experts and Consultants. (

) The Art Advisory Panel of the Commissioner is an IRS Advisory Committee that reviews and evaluates appraisals submitted by taxpayers in support of fair market value claimed on work of art for income, estate and gift tax purposes. Members are appointed without compensation. (
) The Art Advisory Panel meets three to four times per year as follows: a. Section
, Painting and Sculpture – Spring (March/April) and Fall ber/October); and b. Section
, Decorative Arts and Antiques – Once or twice a year and/or November/December). (

) The Director, Art Appraisal Services (AAS), Appeals makes the initial with art experts and initiates the appointee’s paperwork as follows: a. Initiates the appointee’s package ten to twelve weeks prior to the Art Advisory Panel meeting; b. Ensures the appointee completed and signed all required forms in paragraph (
) below; and c. Advises the appointee to bring a valid ID (valid state or federal govern- ment issued picture ID) to the Art Advisory Panel meeting as part of the fingerprint check process. (

Exhibit 6.304.1-1 (11-06-2009) Waiver of Claims - Commissioner’s Art Advisory Panel
Waiver of Claims - Commissioner’s Art Advisory Panel

If requested, I will accept employment as an expert of the Commissioner’s Art Advisory Panel and expect to serve without compensation. I agree in advance to waive any and all claims against the ernment on account of such services.
Exhibit 6.304.1-2 (11-06-2009) Certificate for Appointment of Expert or Consultant
Certificate for Appointment of Expert or Consultant
Proposed Appointee:

The position is necessary and consistent with the definition and use of a consultant ment as described in 5 CFR Part 304 and requires providing advice, views, opinions, alternatives or recommendations on a temporary and/or intermittent basis on issues, problems, or questions presented by a Federal official.
For Expert Appointments Only:

The position is necessary and consistent with the definition and use of an expert appointment as described in 5 CFR Part 304 and requires the services of a specialist with skills superior to those of others in the same profession, occupation, or activity to perform work on a temporary and/or intermittent basis assigned by a Federal official.
The proposed appointee is fully qualified to perform the services described in the statement of

duties. The proposed pay rate is commensurate with the work to be performed and qualifications of the proposed appointee. (Not applicable for appointee to IRS Art Advisory Panel). Review of the financial disclosure report indicates no apparent conflict of interest between the duties to be performed and financial interests and/or other employment of the proposed appointee.
proposed pay rate is commensurate with the work to be performed and qualifications proposed appointee. (Not applicable for appointee to IRS Art Advisory Panel).
Exhibit 6.304.1-3 (11-06-2009) 18 USC § 208(b)(3) Waiver IRS Art Advisory Panel
USC § 208(b)(3) Waiver IRS Art Advisory Panel

the appointing authority for members of the Internal Revenue Service’s Art Advisory Committee I have deter- that the need for the services of ____________ [Appointee] outweighs the potential conflict of interest

created by the Appointee’s financial interest in the field of art. The Art Advisory Committee assists the IRS in making determinations of value for tax purposes of works of art. Given the highly specialized nature of this work, it is necessary to draw the membership of the committee from recognized authorities in the art world. The Appointee is such an authority. With this expertise comes a potential conflict of interest. The appointee is employed as a professional in the field of art, and the appointee or the ap- pointee’s employer may, from time to time, have art work similar to that which is being evaluated. The valuation of this similar art might be affected by the valuation given to the art being reviewed by the committee.

This potential actual or apparent conflict of interest is not sufficient to outweigh the government’s need for the appointee’s services. Moreover, the structure of the advisory committee, consisting of twelve print publishers, distributors, retailers and curators, and its operation as a committee significantly reduce the risk to the ment which any potential conflict poses.
